section.title: Continuous aspect
section.sectiontitle: Use continuous tenses to talk about background actions that are in progress at a particular moment.
section.text1a: I was riding my bike when I saw the car skid off the road.
section.text2a: She was sleeping when the burglary took place.
section.sectiontitle2: Use continuous tenses to talk about 2 actions that are temporary or incomplete.
section.text3a: I'm having a bath at the moment, so can you call back?
section.text4a: She's staying with us until she finds a place of her own.

section.title: <b>Continuous aspect
section.sectiontitle: Use continuous tenses for repeated temporary actions.
section.text1a: I've been working out in the gym every day for one month.
section.text2a: I'm seeing a lot of Pete these days.
section.sectiontitle2: Use continuous tenses for actions in the process of change.
section.text3a: The price of petrol is going up.

section.title: <b>Continuous aspect
section.sectiontitle: Sometimes we use the Past Continuous to sound more polite (less direct).
section.text1a: I was wondering if you could help me.
section.text2: I hoped you could help me with my homework.
section.text2a: I was hoping you could help me with my homework.
section.sectiontitle2: Stative verbs aren't usually used in the continuous. Some stative verbs have a continuous form, but the meaning changes.
section.text3: I'm seeing my friend tomorrow evening.
section.text4: I think the business world is interesting.
section.text4a: I'm thinking of going into business.
